items.title: Deep Pressure for Calming
items.body: Deep pressure input can help calm the nervous system during high arousal states. Try a weighted blanket, firm hugs, or a compression vest. Deep pressure activates the proprioceptive system, providing organizing sensory input. Start with 10-15 minutes and observe your child's response.
items.summary: Use deep pressure to help calm and regulate

items.title: Visual Schedule for Transitions
items.body: Visual schedules help children understand what's coming next, reducing anxiety around transitions. Use pictures or words to show the sequence of activities. Review the schedule before starting and after each activity. This provides predictability and helps children feel more in control.

items.title: Co-Regulation Through Breathing
items.body: When your child is dysregulated, regulate yourself first. Take slow, deep breaths and maintain a calm presence. Your regulation helps them find their own. Model deep breathing without forcing them to participate. Children co-regulate through your calm energy.
items.summary: Regulate yourself to help your child regulate

items.title: Fidget Tools for Focus
items.body: Fidget tools can help with attention and regulation. Try stress balls, fidget spinners, or textured items. These provide sensory input that helps some children focus and stay calm. Let your child choose what works for them. Fidgeting is not a distraction—it's a tool for regulation.
items.summary: Fidget tools support attention and calm

items.title: Noise-Canceling Headphones
items.body: For children who are sensitive to sound, noise-canceling headphones can be life-changing. They reduce overwhelming auditory input in loud environments like stores, schools, or family gatherings. Let your child control when they wear them. This is an accommodation, not avoidance.

items.title: AAC for Communication Support
items.body: Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) can support all children, not just non-speaking ones. Picture boards, communication apps, or sign language can reduce frustration and support expressive communication. AAC doesn't prevent speech—it supports communication in all its forms.
items.summary: AAC supports all forms of communication

items.title: Safe Space for Regulation
items.body: Create a calm, sensory-friendly space where your child can go to regulate. Include soft lighting, comfortable seating, and calming items like weighted blankets or favorite toys. This is not a 'time out' for punishment—it's a safe space for self-regulation. Let them choose when to use it.

items.title: Movement Breaks for Alerting
items.body: When your child seems under-aroused or 'shutdown', movement can help. Try jumping jacks, dancing, running, or playground time. Movement activates the vestibular system and can be alerting. Follow your child's lead on what type of movement feels good.
items.summary: Movement helps with alertness and engagement

items.title: Predictable Bedtime Routine
items.body: A consistent bedtime routine helps signal to the body that it's time to sleep. Include calming activities like reading, bath time, or quiet music. Use a visual schedule so your child knows what to expect. Consistency is key—follow the same order every night.

items.title: Five-Minute Self-Care Break
items.body: You can't pour from an empty cup. Take five minutes for yourself when possible—breathe, stretch, or step outside. Brief moments of self-care help you stay regulated so you can support your child. This isn't selfish; it's necessary. You matter too.
items.summary: Brief self-care helps you stay regulated
